questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) : (C) Osteoma of the Paranasal Sinus • Well-circumscribed, sharply-marginated round and very dense lesions usually less than 2 cm in size • Usually grow into the sinus • Multiple paranasal osteomas are found in Gardner’s syndrome o Multiple osteoma of the mandible and maxilla, along with the frontal, sphenoid and ethmoid sinuses, rarely the long bones or phalanges o Cutaneous and soft tissue tumors o Association between colonic polyps with a predilection to malignant degeneration

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) : (B) Leiomyoma of Esophagus Leiomyoma of Esophagus Imaging findings • Smooth, sharply-marginated mass • Well-defined, intramural (wall) mass lesion that typically intersects wall at 90 degree angle when viewed in profile • As a wall lesion, it may narrow the lumen in one plane and widen it in the orthogonal view (a plane at 90 degrees to the original)

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) : (C) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) Stein-Leventhal Syndrome Imaging • Ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice • Polycystic ovaries are enlarged and rounder than normal with increased stromal echogenicity • There are numerous small cysts, less than 5mm, that line up on the periphery, in a “string-of-pearls” appearance • Ultrasonographic criteria for establishing the diagnosis of PCOS are 10 or more cysts that are 2-8 mm in diameter and are peripherally arranged around an echodense stroma

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gastric Ulcers Imaging Findings of Benign Ulcers Two prerequisites for diagnosis of an ulcer Collection Persistent Ulcer crater-collection of barium on dependent surface which usually projects beyond anticipated wall of stomach in profile (penetration) Hampton’s line-1 mm thin straight line at neck of ulcer in profile view which represents the thin rim of undermined gastric mucosa Ulcer collar-smooth, thick, lucent band at neck of ulcer in profile view representing thicker rim of edematous gastric wall Ulcer mound-smooth, sharply delineated tissue mass surrounding a benign ulcer Ring shadow-thin rim of contrast which represents an ulcer on the non-dependent surface of an air-contrast study Thickened folds radiating directly to the base of the ulcer en face Imaging Findings of Malignant Ulcers Ulcer projects within the anticipated wall of the stomach Ulcer is eccentrically located within the ulcer mound Irregularly shaped ulcer crater Nodular ulcer mound Abrupt transition between normal and abnormal mucosa several cms away from the ulcer crater Rigidity, lack of distensibility and lack of changeability Associated large mass Carmen meniscus sign-a relatively shallow gastric ulcerating malignancy projecting as an ulcer which is always convex inwards to the lumen and which does not project beyond the wall=Kirklin meniscus complex

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pneumococcal pneumonia • Produces inflammatory edema in the alveoli which spreads via pores of Kohn to more lateral alveoli • Extensive infiltrate usually abutting pleural surface • Prominent air bronchograms • Organism is aspirated into the lungs from the upper airways so it shows a predilection for lower lobes

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Imaging findings o Cupping and fraying of metaphysis o Poorly mineralized epiphyseal centers with delayed appearance o Irregular widened epiphyseal plates (increased osteoid) o Increase in distance between end of shaft and epiphyseal center o Cortical spurs projecting at right angles to metaphysis o Coarse trabeculation (not the ground-glass pattern found in scurvy) o Periosteal reaction may be present o Deformities common ? Bowing of long bones ? Molding of epiphysis ? Fractures ? Frontal bossing

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rheumatoid Arthritis Imaging Finding Lateral radiograph of the neck with the head in flexion shows an increased distance between the anterior border of the dens and the posterior border of the anterior tubercle of C1 from ligamentous laxity caused by rheumatoid arthritis. The "pre-dentate space," as this is called, should be less than 3 mm in the adult.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fibromuscular Dysplasia • Location o Renal arteries 85% ? Only 40% have bilateral renal artery involvement o Most often middle and distal 1/3 of renal arteries involved o Less commonly affected: Internal carotid (often bilateral), vertebral, mesenteric, celiac, hepatic, iliac arteries o If FMD is found at any location, one must evaluate carotid arteries for lesions • Imaging Findings o Angiography considered gold standard. CTA and MRA becoming more sensitive. o FMD is characterized by ? Narrowing of the affected vessel with a “string of beads” or nodular appearance , due to focal annular repetitive intimal and medial proliferative changes

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Imaging Manifestations • Acute inflammatory stage o Spasm and irritability o Fine mucosal granularity=earliest finding on air-contrast BE o Spiculated, serrated bowel margins from tiny, multiple ulcerations o Collar button ulcers-from undermining (not specific for UC) o Double-tracking=long, longitudinal ulcers in submucosa o Thumbprinting=from edema of wall o Pseudopolyps=scattered islands of edematous mucosa in a sea of ulcerated mucosa o Widening of the presacral space • Subacute stage o Coarser, more granular mucosa o Inflammatory polyps= frondlike lesions of inflamed mucosa • Chronic stage o Shortening of the colon=may be from spasm of longitudinal muscles or from irreversible fibrosis (lead-pipe colon) o Loss of haustrations on left side of colon o Postinflammatory polyps=filiform polyps=long worm-like lesions Backwash ileitis (5-10%)=wide open ileocecal valve and dilated terminal ileum

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 37 yo male HIV positive
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Imaging on CT and MRI o Toxoplasma Encephalitis ? Thin-walled ring-enhancing lesions, surrounding edema; rarely diffuse encephalitis o Primary CNS Lymphoma ? Ring-enhancing lesions, surrounding edema ? Multiple lesions 50% ? More likely to cross corpus callosum or occur in periependymal areas than TE o PML: ? Multiple areas of demyelination, without contrast-enhancement or edema ? Bilateral, asymmetric; hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pulmonary Thromboembolic Disease •?Imaging findings in embolic disease o Normal chest film common o Plate-like (subsegmental, discoid) atelectasis o Westermark sign represents an area of oligemia (due to vasoconstriction distal to embolus) o Fleischner sign refers to local widening of artery by impaction of embolus (due to distension by clot / pulmonary hypertension developing secondary to peripheral embolization) "Knuckle sign" is term used for abrupt tapering of an occluded vessel distally • o Hampton hump is a pleural-based area of consolidation in the form of a truncated cone with base against pleural surface o "Melting sign" is the sign that refers to disappearance of the opacification within few days to weeks from periphery toward center o Fleischner lines = long-line shadows

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Medullary Nephrocalcinosis. conventional radiograph show amorphous, coarse calcifications throughout both kidneys which correspond the the shape and position of the renal pyramids. Small nodules of calcification clustered in each pyramid

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rounded Atelectasis Occurs as a consequence of diseases with chronic pleural scarring, especially asbestos-related pleural disease and TB Imaging Findings Rounded density at lung base Contiguous to area of pleural disease or superimposed on apparent asbestos-related pleural disease or TB Comet tail on CT: vessels and bronchi converge upon and appear to swirl around mass Crow’s feet — linear bands radiating from mass into lung parenchyma

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Thyroid Ophthalmopathy • Neuroimaging usually reveals thick muscles with tendon sparing o Inferior rectus and medial rectus muscles are most commonly involved Usually bilateral, but may be asymmetric

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) · Rigler’s Triad o Pneumobilia o SBO o Impacted gallstone-usually in the terminal ileum at ileocecal valve

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome Compression of 3rd portion of duodenum between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery (SMA) Females more affected than males Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome. Axial CT scans of the upper abdomen show a dilated 2nd portion of the duodenum (D) just proximal to a narrowed segment of the 3rd portion of the duodenum (green arrow) compressed between the superior mesenteric artery (red arrow) and the aorta (black arrow)

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Typical CT findings include ? Smooth, well delineated, cystic lesion ? Splaying the genioglossus and mylohyoid with a uniformly thin, non-enhancing wall o Ranulas can be slightly increased in attenuation especially the higher the protein content within the fluid

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Imaging Findings CT findings Multiple peripheral parenchymal nodules Cavitation or air bronchogram in more than 89% Cavities are thin-walled and may have no fluid level Wedge-shaped subpleural lesion with apex of lesion directed toward pulmonary hilum Feeding vessel sign = pulmonary artery leading to nodule

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Location • Axial skeleton and large, usually central, appendicular joints • Sacroiliac joint involvement o Hallmark of disease o Only synovial portion of SI joint is involved ? Inferior and anterior portion of joint ? Other enthesopathies like DISH can cause bridging of upper, non-synovial part of joint o Usually site of initial involvement o Bilaterally symmetric o Widened with erosions at first o Then ankylosis • Spine o Usually begins at either thoracolumbar or lumbosacral junctions ? Extends symmetrically without skip areas ? Reiter’s and psoriasis characteristically are asymmetric and have skip areas o Marginal syndesmophyte formation = thin vertical dense spicules bridging the vertebral bodies ? Ossification of outer fibers of annulus fibrosus o Trolley-track sign on AP view = central line of ossification (supraspinous and interspinous ligaments) with two lateral lines of ossification (apophyseal joints) o Bamboo spine on AP view = undulating contour due to syndesmophytes o Prone to fracture resulting in pseudarthrosis o Straightening / squaring of anterior vertebral margins o Reactive sclerosis of corners of vertebral bodies = shiny-corner sign

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Emphysematous Cholecystitis Imaging findings Conventional radiography May show air in the wall or lumen of the gallbladder US findings Indistinct shadowing emanating from wall or lumen of gallbladder “Ring-down effect” or “comet tail” from shadowing from air in gallbladder lumen CT findings of cholecystitis Air in gallbladder wall is diagnostic of this disease

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Circumcaval Ureter • Also known as “circumcaval ureter” • Abnormality in embryogenesis of IVC o Results from abnormal persistence of right subcardinal vein positioned ventral to ureter in the definitive IVC o Developing right ureter courses behind and medial to the IVC o o Right ureter’s course swings medially over pedicle of L3/4 • Passes behind IVC ? Then exits anteriorly between IVC and aorta returning to its normal position ? Produces varying degrees of proximal hydroureteronephrosis ? Retrocaval ureter can be associated with Turner’s syndrome

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Complications of Endotracheal Tubes (ETT) • The tip of the endotracheal tube should be about 5 cm from carina or roughly halfway between the clavicles and the carina • Most often malpositioned in right mainstem bronchus because of shallower angle right main bronchus makes with trachea than does left mainstem bronchus • Right mainstem bronchus intubation will lead to atelectasis of entire left lung and hyperinflation right lung

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Imaging findings Gastric Volvulus. Frontal radiograph from an upper GI examination shows the stomach located in the lower chest in a large hiatal hernia. The greater curvature of the stomach lies superior to the lesser curvature in an organoaxial twist.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Imaging Findings Plain films About 10-20% of gallstones sufficiently calcified to be visible on abdominal films Gallstones are usually round or oval in shape in right upper quadrant Multiple stones may show flattened sides called “faceted stones” "Mercedes Benz" sign is a triradiate collection of nitrogen gas Fills crevices created by shrinkage of cholesterol crystals in the stone Radiolucent fissures usually widest centrally radiating like points of star Mercedes Benz Sign. Mercedes-Benz Hood Ornament Ultrasound is the procedure of choice for gallstone diagnosis

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypertrophic Pulmonary Osteoarthropathy Symmetric periostitis especially involving the tibia and fibula, radius and ulna Most often secondary to an intrathoracic neoplasm or infection Imaging Findings In diametaphyseal regions Periosteal proliferation of new bone First smooth, then undulating rough, most conspicuous on concavity of long bones (dorsal and medial aspects) Soft-tissue swelling ("clubbing") of distal phalanges Bone scan reveals changes early with greater sensitivity and clarity Symmetric diffusely increased uptake along cortical margins of diaphysis and metaphysis of tubular bones of the extremities

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vascular tangles are serpiginous and hyperdense without contrast from the blood pool effect. AVMs may contain punctate or curvilinear calcification. AVMs will enhance

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 35year-old male with headaches
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cerebellar Hemangioblastoma • Benign neoplasm • 80% found in cerebellum o Remainder in spinal cord > medulla > cerebrum • Relationship to von Hippel-Lindau disease • Findings on CT and MRI: o Cystic lesion in the cerebellum with an avidly enhancing mural nodule • Treated with surgical removal of solid nodule Cystic component is not neoplastic

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) AchalasiaImaging Finding : CT scan of the chest demonstrates a markedly dilated esophagus containing barium, debris and a fluid level

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sialolithiasis may show Opaque stone in course of Wharton’s (submandibular) or Stensen’s (parotid) ducts

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Esophageal Candidiasis Monilial Esophagitis Imaging Findings o Discrete plaque-like lesions o Plaques line-up longitudinally = grouping of tiny 1-2 mm nodular filling defects with linear orientation o Larger plaques may coalesce to produce "cobblestone" appearance o Further coalescence produces “shaggy” contour (from coalescent plaques, pseudomembranes, erosions, ulcerations, intramural hemorrhage) in fulminant candidiasis ? More fulminant form is more often associated with AIDS

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) o Multiple small rounded opacities 1-10 mm in size o Usually in upper lobes o Lymph node enlargement common Eggshell calcification of hilar nodes · DDx: Sarcoidosis o Large opacities are conglomerations of small opacities

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bands of increased density at metaphyses of tubular bones (growing bone)

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stage I · Adenopathy alone: Stage 1 · “1-2-3 sign”, “Pawn-broker’s sign”, “Garland sign” · Egg-shell calcification hilar nodes in long-standing sarcoid Stage II · Adenopathy and parenchymal disease Stage 2 Stage III · Parenchymal disease alone Stage IV · End-stage lung disease-Stage 4 · Diffuse fibrosis

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mucocoele of the Appendix Mucocele of the appendix - CT shows low attenuation smooth-walled mass projecting into cecum in region of appendix

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Diskinetic Cilia Syndrome General Considerations o Situs inversus o Sinusitis o Bronchiectasis

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Paget Disease o Osteoporosis circumscripta is well-defined lysis, most commonly in frontal bone producing well-defined geographic lytic lesion in skull ? Represents early destructive phase of disease active stage) Skull xray shows Osteoporosis circumscripta of frontal bone in lytic phase of Paget's disease Other findings include o "Cotton wool" appearance represents mixed lytic and blastic pattern of thickened calvarium (later stage) o Basilar invagination with encroachment on foramen magnum o Sclerosis of skull base • Long bones (almost invariably starts at end of bone) o "Candle flame" or "blade of grass" pattern of lysis is the advancing tip of V-shaped lytic defect in diaphysis of long bone originating in subarticular site • Pelvis o Thickening of iliopectineal line • Spine o "Picture-frame vertebra"

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) o Wedge shaped areas of low attenuation secondary to decreased perfusion o Loss of the ability to distinguish the corticomedullary border o Perinephric stranding

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Psoriatic Arthritis • Almost always accompanies skin disease, especially nail changes • Mostly involves DIP joints of hands > feet • Classical deformity is called “cup-and-pencil deformity” o Erosion of one end of bone with expansion of the base of the contiguous metacarpal • There is usually no osteoporosis

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Imaging findings o Initially, hemithorax may appear opaque because loops are fluid-filled o Paucity of bowel loops beneath the diaphragm o Once air swallowing begins, multiple lucencies contained within bowel are seen ? Respiratory distress may increase as intestine occupies more space o Some loops may remain fluid-filled o Mediastinal shift to the opposite side o Relative paucity of gas in abdomen ? If stomach remains in abdomen, more centrally located than normal o Contrast through an NGT is diagnostic

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tuberculosis, Cavitary. There are large cavities in both apices and airspace disease at the left base on the chest radiograph. On the coronal CT, the thin-walled upper lobe cavities without air-fluid levels are again seen as is the consolidation at the left base. Nodular densities are scattered throughout both lungs.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rugger-Jersey Spine o May be the sole manifestation of renal osteodystrophy o Diffuse chalky density o Thoracolumbar spine with dense end-plates produce appearance of rugger-jersey (rugger jersey spine)

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 57 year-old male
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dissecting Aortic Aneurysm o Chest films ? Mediastinal widening ? Left paraspinal stripe ? Displacement of intimal calcifications ? Apical pleural cap ? Left pleural effusion ? Displacement of endotracheal tube or nasogastric tube

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 32 year old HIV-positive male
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pneumocystis Carinii Pneumonia Pneomocystis Jerovecii • Bilateral diffuse symmetric finely granular / reticular interstitial / airspace infiltrates o Characteristic central location o Rapid progression to diffuse airspace disease Pleural effusion and hilar lymphadenopathy are uncommon • Thin- / thick-walled cysts • Cavities with predilection for upper lobes

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 2 year-old with cough
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Children are affected much more than adults • Location o Usually lower lobe o Most often posterior • May change size rapidly • May have slightly irregular border and contain air bronchogram • Not to be confused with mass in children

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Imaging findings o Sclerosis o Destruction of joint o Fragmentation o Soft tissue swelling from synovitis o Joint effusions o Osteophytosis o Disorganized and disrupted joint o No osteoporosis

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Polyarteritis Nodosa Periarteritis Nodosa Angiographic findings 1-5 mm saccular aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in 60-75% of cases Secondary to necrosis of internal elastic lamina Luminal irregularities and stenoses Arterial occlusions and small tissue infarcts

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Polyarteritis Nodosa Periarteritis Nodosa Angiographic findings 1-5 mm saccular aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in 60-75% of cases Secondary to necrosis of internal elastic lamina Luminal irregularities and stenoses Arterial occlusions and small tissue infarcts

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Polyarteritis Nodosa Periarteritis Nodosa Angiographic findings 1-5 mm saccular aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in 60-75% of cases Secondary to necrosis of internal elastic lamina Luminal irregularities and stenoses Arterial occlusions and small tissue infarcts

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Saw-tooth appearance to the colon, usually sigmoid, with shortening of bowel, crowding of haustra and picket-fencing of folds Diverticulitis. There is an abscess in the left lower quadrant (red arrow), with thickening of the bowel wall, infiltration of the pericolonic fat (yellow arrow) and multiple areas of extraluminal air.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Imaging Findings • Originally produces patchy, diffuse air space consolidation that can be rapidly progressive • Coalesces near hila • May have adenopathy and pleural effusion • Produces widespread nodules • Numerous, small, punctate calcifications Differential Diagnosis • Histoplasmosis • Alveolar microlithiasis

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Congenital Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation Developmental hamartomatous abnormality with cyst production Communicate with the tracheobronchial tree Usually receives blood supply from pulmonary circulation and drains to pulmonary circulation

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Polycystic Kidney Disease Multiple cysts in the both kidneys and liver is in NCCT abdomen

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? Unenhanced CT of the Brain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fahr Disease. Unenhanced CT reveals dense calcifications within the basal ganglia, subcortical white matter of the posterior parietal lobes, and the dentate nuclei of the cerebellum.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) There are expansile, geographic, lytic lesions in the shaft of the humerus with endosteal scalloping and cortical thinning. The arm is bowed. The matrix has a ground-glass appearance to it

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 42 year-old female with chest pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Imaging Findings • Wormian bones • Intersutural bones, especially seen in the lambdoid and posterior sagittal sutures • Thinness and underossification of calvarium in early infancy • Persistent metopic suture • Midline suture in frontal bone • Brachycephaly and prominent bossing • Hypoplastic paranasal sinuses, including mastoids • Delayed or defective dentition • Hypoplasia or absence of clavicles

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 73 year-old with left arm pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pancoast Tumor (Superior Sulcus Tumor) Imaging Findings • MRI is probably more sensitive than CT in identifying extension of the tumor into adjacent soft tissues and bone Pancoast Tumor. Frontal chest radiograph demonstrates a mass in the left lung apex There is associated destruction of the left 2nd and 3rd ribs posteriorly. The combination of an apical mass with rib destruction is characteristic for a Pancoast Tumor.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 53 year-old with mild shortness of breath
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Imaging signs of Left Lower Lobe Atelectasis • Wedge-like density behind heart with base of triangle on the left hemidiaphragm and the apex at the hilum on frontal view • Silhouetting of all or just the medial portion of the left hemidiaphragm • Posterior displacement of the major fissure on the lateral view • Hilum may be displaced inferiorly • There may be a a spine sign due to superimposition of the non-aerated lower lobe and the spine on the lateral view

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 59 year-old male with change in bowel habits
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Adrenal Calcifications

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 27 year-old male with knee pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Conventional radiography is the imaging study of first choice • Lateral view should demonstrate most fractures • Axial (skyline, sunrise) may show vertical fractures best • Osteochondral sleeve fractures show avulsion of the inferior pole of the patella • If the x-ray beam is oriented horizontally and image is obtained cross-table, a fat-fluid level (lipohemarthrosis) may be present

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 50 year-old female with chest pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Imaging findings • Conventional radiography • Suggestive but not usually diagnostic • "Water bottle configuration" is symmetrically enlarged cardiac silhouette • Major DDX is cardiomegaly • "Fat-pad sign" • Produced by separation of retrosternal from epicardial fat line >2 mm • Uncommon but specific • Rapidly enlarging cardiac silhouette with normal pulmonary vascularity • Echocardiogram • Study of choice • Echo-free fluid between the visceral and parietal pericardium • Early effusions accumulate posteriorly first • > 1cm is usually defined as a “large” effusion • CT • May detect small effusions (50cc) • Fluid-filled space surrounding the myocardium • Early effusions accumulate posteriorly first

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 49 year-old female with dull right lower quadrant pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) o Relatively insensitive, a conventional radiograph of the pelvis may identify ? A soft tissue mass, if large enough ? A fat-containing mass of lower density than the surrounding soft tissue, a finding which is diagnostic ? Characteristic calcifications, such as ? “Popcorn” calcifications in uterine fibroids ? Rim-like calcifications in ovarian cystic lesions or sometimes uterine fibroids ? A tooth or other bone (e.g. clavicle)

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 6 year-old with difficulty breathing and drooling
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Lateral radiograph should be taken in the erect position only, as o Supine position may close off airway • Enlargement of epiglottis o “Larger than your thumb”

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 43 year-old in a motor vehicle accident
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Subcapsular hematoma (and renal laceration) of the left kidney • Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis is the study of choice o Delayed scans may be needed to detect extraluminal contrast

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 36 year-old with severe headache
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) • Be bloody Imaging findings • Unenhanced CT of the brain is the study of choice for establishing presence of SAH • CT angiography has replaced conventional angiography in most institutions for the identification and location of the aneurysm itself • Acute hemorrhage appears as high-attenuation (white) material that fills the normally black subarachnoid spaces • DSA remains the gold standard for cerebral aneurysm.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 79 year-old with abdominal pain following colonoscopy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Free Intraperitoneal Air • Imaging findings o Large collection of gas o Abdominal distension, no gastric air-fluid level o "Football sign" = large pneumoperitoneum outlining entire abdominal cavity o "Double wall sign" = "Rigler sign" = air on both sides of bowel as intraluminal gas and free air outside (usually requires >1,000 mL of free intraperitoneal gas + intraperitoneal fluid) o "Telltale triangle sign" = triangular air pocket between 3 loops of bowel o "Inverted V sign" = outline of both lateral umbilical ligaments (containing inferior epigastric vessels) o "Urachus sign" = outline of middle umbilical ligament o Single large area of hyperlucency over the liver o Doge's cap sign = triangular collection of gas in Morrison pouch (posterior hepatorenal space) o Outline of falciform ligament = long vertical line to the right of midline extending from ligamentum teres notch to umbilicus; most common structure outlined o Ligamentum teres notch = inverted V-shaped area of hyperlucency along undersurface of liver o Ligamentum teres sign = air outlining fissure of ligamentum teres hepatis (= posterior free edge of falciform ligament) seen as vertically oriented sharply defined slitlike / oval area of hyperlucency between 10th and 12th rib within 2.5-4.0 cm of right vertebral border 2-7 mm wide and 6-20 mm long o "Saddlebag / mustache / cupola sign" = gas trapped below central tendon of diaphragm o Parahepatic air = gas bubble lateral to right edge of liver

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 22 year-old with diplopia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Blowout Fracture of the Orbit Imaging Findings • CT of the facial bones is the imaging study of choice • Orbital emphysema • Fracture of the floor or medial wall of the orbit o Depression of the fracture fragment(s) • Soft-tissue mass extending into the maxillary sinus • Complete or partial opacification of the ipsilateral maxillary sinus from hemorrhage or edema

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 18 year-old female with pain in foot
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Avascular Necrosis, Osteonecrosis, Osteochondrosis • Early signs are sclerosis of 2nd MT head and widening of joint space • Later there is fragmentation and collapse

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 62 year-old male with right upper quadrant pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) o Conventional radiography ? May show air in the wall or lumen of the gallbladder o US findings ? Indistinct shadowing emanating from wall or lumen of gallbladder ? “Ring-down effect” or “comet tail” from shadowing from air in gallbladder lumen o CT findings of cholecystitis ? Air in gallbladder wall is diagnostic of this disease

choices.text: Fracture of hook of the hamate

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 26 year-old with pain in wrist following fall
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) ? Triangular appearance of lunate on frontal projection ? Produces volar (anterior) dislocation and forward rotation of lunate ? Concave distal surface of lunate comes to face anteriorly • The lunate cup “points” towards the palm

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 74 year-old male with dysuria
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) • Imaging findings o Calculi that form in a “hollow” viscus, such as bladder calculi, typically will have a laminated type of calcification consisting of alternating layers of heavily calcified and matrix materials o Initial imaging study of choice is a KUB (kidneys, ureters and bladder) radiograph using conventional radiography o Unenhanced spiral CT scan is highly sensitive in diagnosing calculi along the urinary tract and has largely replace intravenous pyelography and cystography

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 47 year-old with dyspnea
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Constrictive Pericarditis. This axial CT image of the chest is displayed using bone windows to show the calcifications of the pericardium. There are bilateral pleural effusions present a common finding in constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 21 year-old with lump near knee
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • MRI can be used to asses surrounding soft tissues and to measure the thickness of the cartilage cap, which can be important in evaluating for malignant generation o A thick cartilaginous cap (>1 cm) in adults should raise the possibility of malignant transformation • Osteochondromas can either be sessile (flat) or pedunculated (stalk)

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Liver Metastases • In general, most metastases are hypovascular, but some primaries characteristically have hypervascular metastases • Hypervascular metastases o Carcinoids o Leiomyosarcomas o Neuroendocrine tumors o Renal carcinomas o Thyroid carcinomas o Choriocarcinomas • CT is the study of choice for evaluating liver metastases • Most liver metastases are hypovascular compared with surrounding parenchyma and therefore most lesions appear either hypoattenuating or isoattenuating relative to the surrounding normal liver

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Imaging findings • Characteristic finding is bilaterally symmetric low attenuation lesions in the globus palladi. There may also be low density lesions in the cerebral and cerebellar white matter, sparing subcortical fibers

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Supracardiac-Type I-TAPVR. The heart has a "snowman shape." The pulmonary veins drain into an enlarged vertical vein which in turn drains into the brachiocephalic vein and then to the superior vena cava . The vasculature is shunt vasculature.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 18 year-old female presents with vaginal bleeding and a B-HCG over 440,000; LMP was 2 months ago. Sagittal and Transverse Ultrasound Images of Uterus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Classic sonographic appearance of a complete mole o “Snowstorm” or “granular” appearance ? Central heterogeneous mass with numerous anechoic (cystic) spaces o Low resistance arterial and venous flow o Absence of embryo or fetus • When sonographic appearance and hCG levels are suspicious for hydatidiform mole, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histology

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 41 year-old male with shortness of breath
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Idiopathic Giant Bullous Emphysema Imaging Findings • Bullous disease asymmetrically involved the upper lobes predominantly • On high-resolution CT, bullae range from 1 to 20 cm in diameter, mostly in the range of 2-8 cm in diameter • Bullous disease asymmetrically involved the upper lobes predominantly Differential Diagnosis • Mistaking a large bulla for a pneumothorax and inserting a chest tube into it will lead to a pneumothorax • Find the visceral pleural white line to identify a pneumothorax and, when in doubt, do CT • Bullae compress adjacent lung and can predispose to pneumothorax

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 57 year-old female with right upper quadrant pain Close-up of RUQ of Abdominal Radiograph
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Imaging Findings Dense opacification of the gallbladder lumen seen on CT or conventional radiography Always associated with cholelithiasis or choledocholithiasis May form fluid-fluid level in conventional radiographs exposed with horizontal beam

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 37 year-old female with abdominal pain Frontal radiograph of the pelvis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Spotted Bone Disease • Well-defined sclerotic lesions clustered symmetrically around joints • The long axis of the lesion is typically lined-up with the long axis of the bone • Bone islands may have a thorny appearance

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 42 year-old with chronic headaches Unenhanced axial CT scans of head
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) General Considerations • Benign, epithelium-lined cysts • Usually found in adults in their 40s or 50s • Arise from anterosuperior aspect of 3rd ventricle near the foramina of Monro • Cysts are usually filled with a thick mucus-like material although some are filled with thinner, serous fluid • Typically asymptomatic • Colloid cysts may obstruct the foramina leading to hydrocephalus • CT o Round mass in anterior 3rd ventricle with high attenuation o Hydrocephalus

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 33 year-old male with back asymmetry Frontal radiograph of the chest
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) • Failure of normal descent of scapula from initial mid-cervical position to final thoracic position. o Descent should occur between sixth and eight weeks gestation. • Often occurs as part of Klippel-Feil Deformity (fusion of cervical vertebrae). o Also can occur with absent or fused ribs, chest wall asymmetry, cervical ribs, and/or congenital scoliosis. • 50% of cases have an omovertebral bone (bony or fibrous connection between scapula and the spinous process, lamina or transverse process of a vertebral body between C4 and C7)

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 58 year-old male with history of seizures Non contrast-enhanced axial CT scans of brain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Imaging Findings • Involuted, degenerated cysts calcify • Calcified cysts are usually not associated with surrounding inflammation

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 51 year-old with heel pain Lateral radiograph of the foot
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Lucent lesion with sclerotic margin • Central sclerotic bulls-eye (pathognomonic) • Cockade image-resembles the badge or rose worn upon a hat

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 41 year-old with frequency and dysuria Unenhanced, coronal reformatted CT scan of abdomen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (e) Imaging Findings • Plain films may show large globular, amorphous calcifications or smaller nondescript stones • Intravenous pyelography or, more recently, CT urograms can be diagnostic • Affected kidney may contrast-enhance on CT • Renal calcification is common • Stones, focal or extensive globular calcification, ring-like calcifications of papillary necrosis • Cortical scarring • "Smudged" papillae (moth-eaten) –irregular due to inflammation and necrosis • Several cysts surrounding a calyx with cortical thinning • Infundibular strictures • Hydrocalyces without dilatation of renal pelvis, or • Hydronephrosis • "Putty kidney" – sacs of caseous, necrotic material • Autonephrectomy – small, shrunken kidney with dystrophic calcification • When ureters are involved, usually the upper or lower third • Beading (sawtooth ureter), corkscrew, strictures • Bladder involvement rarely leads to calcification of wall (think schistosomiasis) • Reflux, thickening of bladder wall (thimble bladder)

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? 71 year-old male with right lower quadrant pain Axial CT scan of upper abdomen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Imaging Findings • On CT scan, mucinous material has similar density to fat and appears heterogeneous. • Scalloped surface of the liver, spleen, and mesentery • Rim-like calcifications are common • Undersurface of the diaphragm may be thickened by large cystic masses of mucinous tumor

questions.text: What sign is depicted on this image? 46 year-old with back pain Frontal radiograph of lumbar spine
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Inverted Napoleon Hat Sign • Occurs with marked anterolisthesis of L5 on S1 • Visible on frontal radiograph of lumbar spine • Implies the presence of bilateral spondylolysis and significant spondylolisthesis

questions.text: What sign is depicted on this image? 58 year-old with abdominal pain and diarrhea Axial CT view of abdomen with oral contrast
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • The sign was originally described as alternating edematous haustral folds separated by mucosal ridges filled with oral contrast material Accordion Sign. White oval highlights markedly thickened bowel wall with oral contrast trapped between haustral folds in a patient with known C difficile colitis. This is the "accordion sign."

questions.text: What's the name of this sign? 78 year-old male who fell off ladder Frontal and lateral radiographs of femur
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: What's the name of this sign? 53 year-old male with cough Frontal Chest Radiograph
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Calcification around the periphery of lymph nodes • Most commonly seen in silicosis and coal-worker's pneumoconiosis • Also seen in sarcoid • Rarely in post-irradiated Hodgkin disease, blastomycosis, scleroderma, amyloid and histoplasmosis

questions.text: What's the name of this sign? 45 year-old male with hemoptysis Axial CT scan of chest
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Monad's Sign and Air Crescent Sign • Terminology can be confusing as a similar sign is described for both invasive aspergillosis and secondary, non-invasive, saprophytic aspergillosis • Invasive aspergillosis typically occurs in immunocompromised patients • It frequently begins with a solid-appearing peripheral soft tissue opacity that, through infarction and retraction, produces a cavity with a density within it • The density is necrotic lung tissue, not the fungus ball in non-invasive aspergillosis • Invasive aspergillosis • On CT, there may be ground glass densities in the area around the nodular density called the "halo sign" and indicative of hemorrhage

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 42 year-old male with acute abdominal pain Contrast-enhanced Axial CT of Abdomen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Imaging findings Study of choice is contrast-enhanced CT Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas Heterogeneous enhancement Indistinct or shaggy margins Infiltration of the peripancreatic fat Fluid collections in the peripancreatic and anterior pararenal spaces

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 15 year-old boy with knee pain Lateral Radiograph of Knee
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Imaging Findings • Best seen on lateral knee • Irregular ossification or fragmentation of tibial tubercle • Separated from remainder of tibial tubercle • Soft tissue swelling • Calcification in or thickening of the patellar tendon

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 50 year-old male with frequency Radiograph from Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Imaging Findings • Increased lucency in the pelvis on conventional radiography due to fat deposition • Inverted teardrop-shaped bladder (pear-shaped bladder) • Ureters may be dilated and may be medially or laterally displaced distally • Hydronephrosis, usually bilaterally • The rectum is elongated and symmetrically compressed • Rectum may be displaced cephalad (tower rectum) • Increased distance between seminal vesicles and posterior bladder wall

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 60 year-old male with pain in finger Frontal radiograph of hand
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Leri’s Disease, Flowing Periosteal Hyperostosis Imaging Findings • Sclerotic lesions of cortical bones, usually in the diaphysis, that resemble “candle-wax-dripping” • Cortical hyperostosis with an undulating appearance usually affecting one side of a bone

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 43 year-old with vague abdominal pain Contrast-enhanced axial CT image in mid-abdomen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Imaging Findings • CT is probably study of choice now • Isthmus (fused portion) is usually functioning renal parenchyma but can be fibrous • Isthmus is anterior to aorta and inferior vena cava and posterior to inferior mesenteric artery

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 24 year-old in motor vehicle rollover accident Frontal Supine Chest Radiograph
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Imaging Findings • Chest radiographs are invariably performed first • Two or more fractures in two or three or more contiguous ribs • Chest x-rays tend to underestimate the number of fractures Chest CT is also invariably performed, and may show • Rib fractures • Pulmonary contusion (almost always) • Airspace disease representing hemorrhage into the alveoli usually subjacent to the point of impact • Pulmonary laceration • Lacerations in the lung may be blood-containing, air-containing, or both • Frequently masked by the surrounding pulmonary contusion • Pneumothorax (very common) • Since the severity of the injury means a supine radiograph will be performed, pneumothoraces may only be seen on chest CT • Hemothorax (common) • Pneumomediastinum • Subcutaneous emphysema • Mediastinal hemorrhage • Aortic injuries

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 75 year-old with abdominal pain; the sign shown is called the: Supine radiograph of abdomen (disregard the gallstones)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Colon cutoff sign (here shown in mesenteric ischemia) Colon Cut-off Sign White arrow on conventional radiograph points to air in colon which abruptly terminates at the splenic flexure.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 23 year-old female with pain in both wrists Frontal radiographs of each wrist
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Imaging Findings • Exaggerated radial inclination • “V-shaped” proximal carpal row • Dorsal dislocation of the ulnar head

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 12 year-old male with knee pain Right Knee-AP View
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Imaging Findings • Geographic lytic lesion arising in the epiphysis of a child • May extend to adjacent metaphysis • Counterpart of chondroblastoma in a child is giant cell tumor (GCT) of an adult • GCT arise later in life (20-30) • Frequently extend to metaphysis

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 58 year-old male with abdominal pain and constipation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Abdominal plain films usually diagnostic Inverted U-shaped appearance of distended sigmoid loop Largest and most dilated loops of bowel are seen with volvulus Loss of haustra Coffee-bean sign à midline crease corresponding to mesenteric root in a greatly distended sigmoid Sigmoid volvulus – bowel loop points to RUQ Cecal Volvulus – bowel loop points to LUQ Dilated cecum comes to rest in left upper quadrant Bird’s-beak or bird-of-prey sign à seen on barium enema as it encounters the volvulated loop CT scan useful in assessing mural wall ischemia

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 18 month old male with swelling of wrist
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E)

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 51 year-old man with elevated creatinine
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Subperiosteal resorption along the radial aspects of the middle phalanges of the index, middle and ring fingers, a finding virtually pathognomonic for hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 46 year old female with back pain Contrast-enhanced axial CT of lower abdomen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Corduroy (aka accordion, honeycomb, polka-dot) spine from coarse trabeculae seen in cross section Thickened vertebral trabeculae produce a polka-dot appearance

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 19 year old involved in motor vehicle accident Non-enhanced axial CT of brain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Result of deceleration injuries, especially in high-speed motor vehicle collisions o Also a major cause of morbidity in “Shaken Baby Syndrome” o cause of persistent vegetative state following trauma • Result of rotational shear injuries that most often occur at the gray-white matter junction o Extent of injury is usually worse than that depicted by imaging o MRI is the preferred method of study but CT is usually more available o Small petechial hemorrhages located at gray-white matter junction and corpus callosum o Gradient-echo sequences are very useful in demonstrating paramagnetic effects of petechial hemorrhages

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 51 year old with abdominal pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Congenital saccular outpouching of distal ureter into the urinary bladder CT urogram Upper pole moiety produces drooping lily sign by displacing lower pole downward and laterally Ureter from upper pole moiety inserts in a more inferior and medial location than lower pole moiety (Weigert-Meyer Rule) Cobra-head appearance of the dilated distal ureter

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 63 year old with diarrhea
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Difficile colitis (Pseudomembranous colitis) • CT Accordion sign • Contrast trapped within very thick haustra produce alternating bands of high and low density

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 48 year old with back pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Originates from embryonic remnants of the notochord Location 50% occur in sacrum 35% at skull base around clivus Benign tumors but may locally invade and compress 15% in remainder of spine Imaging Findings Large presacral mass (>10cm) with displacement of the rectum and/or bladder Solid tumor with cystic areas Destroys multiple sacral and coccygeal segments May have amorphous calcifications, especially peripherally May cross the sacroiliac joint CT is helpful in defining bone destruction and calcification within lesion

questions.text: What's the most likely diagnosis? 10 year-old male with pain in shoulder
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Simple Bone Cyst, Solitary Bone Cyst Most common in proximal humerus (in patients under 20) and femur in skeletally immature male Solitary, lytic metaphyseal lesion adjacent to, but not crossing, the epiphyseal plate Migrates towards diaphysis during growth of child Fallen Fragment Sign represents a fragment of bone that falls into the cyst and then into a dependent position

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came with complaints of acute abdominal pain. A plain X-ray abdomen erect was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pneumoperitoneum The above X-ray clearly shows the presence of subdiaphragmatic free gas in the right upper quadrant.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of a road traffic accident. The finding in the axial CT image is as shown below. It is most commonly caused due to bleeding from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Middle meningeal artery The given CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, characteristic of an extradural hemorrhage. It is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery. As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

questions.text: Identify the artery marked by red arrow.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Superior mesenteric artery The artery marked by the red arrow is the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which gives rise to various branches that supply the small intestines, cecum, ascending, and part of the transverse colon. The CT also depicts nutcracker syndrome, a left renal vein entrapment syndrome characterized by extrinsic compression of the left renal vein (marked by a red arrow), most commonly between the abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery. This syndrome is one of the postulated reasons for left- sided varicoceles being more common than the right side.

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Craniopharyngioma A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke’s pouch and arises near the pituitary stalk, commonly extending into the suprasellar cistern.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chronic calicific pancreatitis As the given image shows, there are multiple calcifications within the region of the pancreas, which is characteristic of chronic calcific pancreatitis. This condition results from long-standing inflammation of the pancreas, leading to the deposition of calcium. Chronic pancreatitis is often associated with alcohol abuse, genetic factors, or recurrent acute pancreatitis. The calcifications are a hallmark feature and help differentiate it from other abdominal pathologies.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with seizures and her radiological image is as given below. Knowing that the MR spectroscopy of the lesion showed elevated choline, alanine, and lactate, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neurocysticercosis The given radiological image and history of seizures suggests a diagnosis of neurocysticercosis. Neurocysticercosis presents with seizures, hydrocephalus, raised ICP, and may even cause signs of chronic meningitis. The given image shows multilobulated cystic lesions (with scolex) in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulose).

questions.text: The pelvic ultrasound of a 35-year-old woman is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Monochorionic twins The pelvic ultrasound in a 35-year-old woman shows the ‘T-sign’ seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. In monochorionic pregnancy, the chorion does not extend between the layers of the intertwin membrane. Thus, the inter-twin membrane comes to an abrupt halt in a T-configuration at the edge of the amniotic sac. In contrast, in a dichorionic pregnancy, the sonographic image depicts a ‘twin-peak’ sign or the ‘lambda sign” as the chorion is present between the intertwin membrane. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen inserted between the amniochorion layers.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue and difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. On examination, she has pallor, angular stomatitis, and a bald tongue. There is no history of weight loss. Her hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL and a peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. A barium swallow shows the following findings. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Plummer-Vinson syndrome The above clinical and laboratory findings along with the barium swallow showing an esophageal web suggest a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Plummer-Vinson syndrome, also known as Patterson-Kelly-Brown syndrome, refers to a triad of iron deficiency anemia, dysphagia, and the presence of an esophageal web. These patients present with anemia, dysphagia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, koilonychia, etc. The iron deficiency is thought to cause mucosal injury during swallowing which forms a web during the process of healing. The post-cricoid region sustains the maximum trauma during swallowing, and so this is the most common site of web formation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a Doppler study. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normal diastolic flow The given Doppler image indicates normal diastolic flow in the umbilical arteries. Umbilical artery vessels are characterized by forward, low-resistance flow. As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance Indices, so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases. S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases (S represents the peak systolic flow or velocity, and D indicates the end-diastolic flow or velocity).

questions.text: In patients with pneumonia, what is the most common causative organism that can lead to this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Staphylococcus aureus The chest x-ray depicts a pneumatocele adjacent to the left heart border (black arrow in the image below). The most common cause of pneumatocele formation is Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with thunderclap headaches and seizures. There is no history of trauma. Non-contrast CT was done and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Subarachnoid hemorrhage The clinical features of a thunderclap headache and seizures with the given CT scan showing hyperdense areas corresponding to blood in the subarachnoid basal cisterns suggest a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of low-grade fever and progressive chest pain. Chest X-ray revealed the following. Considering the symptoms and imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pericardial effusion The given image shows a globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow, called the money bag appearance. Considering the above symptoms and the chest X-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis is pericardial effusion.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic alcoholism presented with severe right-sided upper abdominal pain. On examination, her SOFA score was 3. An abdominal CT was done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Emphysematous cholecystitis The given clinical scenario along with the CT showing gas within the wall of the gallbladder is suggestive of emphysematous cholecystitis. Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare form of acute cholecystitis where gallbladder wall necrosis causes gas formation intramurally or intraluminally. This condition occurs most frequently in elderly males or patients with diabetes, Secondary infection of the gallbladder wall with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii/ C. perfringens leads to emphysematous cholecystitis, and aerobes such as Escherichia coli may also be isolated. Patients present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Crepitus is present on physical examination.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis shown in the image below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cervical rib The given X-ray shows cervical rib. Patients with a cervical rib usually show a lump and tenderness in the supraclavicular fossa. The pallor and paresthesias are due to vascular and neural compressions respectively. A radiograph of the neck is useful in detecting a cervical rib

questions.text: A two-day-old neonate with abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium underwent a barium enema study, as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hirschsprung’s disease The given clinical scenario and the barium enema showing a dilated right colon, with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon, are together suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. The most important sign on barium enema is a sudden change of calibre from the narrow aganglionic segment and dilated proximal bowel. Hirschsprung disease is characterized by aganglionosis (absence of ganglion cells) in the distal colon and rectum. This may occur due to the failure of neuroblasts in neural crest cells to migrate into bowel segments or the degeneration of already migrated neuroblasts. Hence, functional obstruction develops as a result of a spasm in the denervated colon

questions.text: Given below is the CT abdomen of a patient who presented with diarrhea. He is most likely to be suffering from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pseudomembranous colitis The CT image depicts the accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis. Clostridium difficle infection (CDI) commonly caused by the disruption of the commensal colonic microflora, due to prolonged antimicrobial use, especially antibiotics like cephalosporins, ampicillin, clindamycin, and fluoroquinolones. The more severe form of CDI is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Toxigenic Clostridium difficile produces toxin A (an enterotoxin) and toxin B (a cytotoxin), damaging the epithelial-cell barrier function and causing diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation, which initially appear as small whitish-yellow plaques and later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. The patient also presents with fever, abdominal pain, and leukocytosis.

questions.text: The following spot film was taken while performing a voiding cystourethrogram for a 2-year-old girl. Which of the following investigations will be useful for the evaluation of renal scarring in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tc 99m DMSA The given voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) shows a unilateral grade 4 vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). The investigation of choice to evaluate for renal scarring in reflux nephropathy is the Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan. It Is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for the detection of scarring and pyelonephritis. DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex as it binds within the proximal tubules of the cortex with longer retention”than other agents.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is shown in the image below. What other investigations should be done to confirm the diagnosis in this patient? UGIE- Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy PET- Positron emission tomography
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) UGIE + manometry The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow showing bird beak sign are suggestive of achalasia cardia. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) and manometry should be done to confirm the diagnosis. Achalasia is a motility disorder and is less common. It typically presents as dysphagia for solids and liquids. Other features such as regurgitation and chest pain are also present.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Renal angiomyolipoma The given CT image shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in colour) that indicate fatty tissue. This is suggestive of renal angiomyolipomas. Angiomyolipomas (AMLs) are benign tumours that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. It is commonly seen in adults between 30 and 50 years of age, with a female predilection. AMLS predominantly affect the kidneys, though they can occur in other sites such as the liver (a common extra-renal location) and less frequently in the ovary, fallopian tube, spermatic cord, palate, and colon.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the non-contrast CT scan of a patient given below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hydatid cyst The given CT image shows a cyst in the liver with the serpent sign and areas of calcification, which are suggestive of hydatid disease. Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of dogs as definitive hosts and humans as accidental intermediate hosts. Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver. Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice.
